captions.text:
If you travel by train to Baden-Baden,
you’ll need to take a bus into town.
The railway line goes along the Rhine valley,

but Baden-Baden in squeezed in
between the hills of the Black Forest.

The Romans discovered the natural
hot springs of water
bubbling up from 2 kilometres down, over a mile,
at a temperature of 68°C, or 154°F.

The remains of the original Roman baths
can still be seen.

Nearby, the 19th-century Friedrichsbad
represents the renaissance of Baden-Baden.

It was in fact the nearby Congress of Rastatt
from 1797 to 1799

that led to the rediscovery of Baden-Baden
as a spa town,

which is why so much of the architecture
is from the decades immediately following.

It became popular with the rich and powerful,
and it shows:

even some of the gift shops
don’t display their prices,

on the grounds that if you have to ask,
you can’t afford it.

It was partly the visitors who were responsible
for the curious name of the town.

Originally, it was simply called “Baden”,
in reference to the baths.

The local Margrave,
resident in the castle of Hohenbaden,
acquired “Baden” as part of his title.
And so the Margraviate of Baden was established.

But there were other places named “Baden”
in Germany, Austria and Switzerland,
and so this Baden became known as “Baden in Baden”.

But the many visitors to the place
simply referred to it as “Baden-Baden”,

and the name stuck.
In 1931, it became official.

The rich and the powerful considered Baden-Baden
to be the summer capital of Europe,
while Paris was the winter capital.
They came here to relax and take the waters.

The rather grand pump room contains
fourteen exquisite murals,
which need careful and painstaking maintenance.

One thing the rich and powerful loved doing
was playing cards,

and so when the Kurhaus, the spa hotel,
was built in 1824, it housed a casino,
now considered the most beautiful in the world.

There are guided tours available,
but only in the mornings.

To see the town from a different perspective,
you can take the bus to Merkurwald,

from where a funicular railway will
take you up to the summit of the Merkur,
all the better to appreciate the way

the Black Forest rises dramatically
from the Rhine valley.
It was very hazy when we went,
but nobody was going to let that spoil their fun.

Baden-Baden also has a less-well-known attraction:
the Rose Garden.
New varieties of rose are showcased here,
and compete for the Golden Rose of Baden-Baden,
one of the most prestigious awards in Europe.
